description: Smallest k such that k*n has even digits and is a palindrome or becomes a palindrome when 0's are added on the left.
comments: Every integer n has a multiple of the form 99...9900...00. To see that n has a multiple that's a palindrome (allowing 0's on the left) with even digits, let 9n divide 99...9900...00; then n divides 22...2200...00. - _Dean Hickerson_, Jun 29 2001
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..80
P. De Geest, Smallest multipliers to make a number palindromic.
mathematica: a[n_] := For[k = 1, True, k++, id = IntegerDigits[k*n]; If[AllTrue[id, EvenQ], rid = Reverse[id]; If[id == rid || (id //. {d__, 0} :> {d}) == (rid //. {0, d__} :> {d}), Return[k]]]]; a[0] = 1; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 70}] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Apr 01 2016 *)
prog: (ARIBAS): stop := 500000; for n := 0 to 75 do k := 1; test := true; while test and k < stop do m := omit_trailzeros(n*k); if test := not all_even(m) or m <> int_reverse(m) then inc(k); end; end; if k < stop then write(k," "); else write(-1," "); end; end;(Haskell)a061797 0 = 1a061797 n = head [k | k <- [1..], let x = k * n,                 all (`elem` "02468") $ show x, a136522 (a004151 x) == 1]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Feb 01 2012
crossrefs: Cf. A050782, A062293 A061674. Values of k*n are given in A062293.
author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Jun 17 2001
